scenesList.scene_6: Introduction to the Corresponding Angles Theorem
scenesList.scene_8: Introduction to the Alternate Interior Angles Theorem
scenesList.scene_10: Introduction to the Triangle Angle Sum Theorem

start.title:
Euclid’s Path

A Journey Through Geometry
start.description: Embark on a journey through ancient geometry in Alexandria's Great Library. Guided by Hypatia, you'll discover fundamental theorems and learn how triangles sum to 180 degrees. Through logical reasoning, you'll unlock principles that have shaped civilization, becoming a master of mathematical proof.

S2_D1_F3_C0.heading: Welcome to Alexandria’s Great Library!
S2_D1_F3_C0.body: A new day dawns over Alexandria. The morning sun casts long rays through the high windows of the Library, illuminating dust motes dancing above scrolls and mathematical instruments. In the geometric workshop, Hypatia and Theon are already at work when Akila arrives.

S3.S3_D1_F6_C1: After our work with the compass yesterday, I stayed up all night with Euclid's Elements, the foundational mathematics textbook written by Euclid.
S3.S3_D2_F7_C2: And what did you discover in its pages?
S3.S3_D3_F8_C1: Something fascinating - in every triangle I drew, when I added the three angles together, they always equal 180°! But... I feel lost trying to understand why this happens.
S3.S3_D4_F9_C2: Ah, you've discovered both the beauty and the challenge of mathematical proof. Tell me, Akila, have you ever seen a chain being forged?
S3.S3_D5_F10_C1: Yes! At the metalworkers' district. Each link must be perfect, or the whole chain fails.
S3.S3_D6_F11_C3: And what comes first when making a chain?
S3.S3_D7_F12_C1: The first link must be the strongest.... But what does this have to do with mathematics?
S3.S3_D8_F13_C2: Exactly! To prove why triangle angles always sum to 180°, we must begin with our strongest links - what we call postulates.
S3.S3_D9_F14_C1: Postulates? What exactly are those?
S3.S3_D10_F15_C3: They are the foundations upon which all geometric truth is built — statements so fundamental, we accept them without proof.
S3.S3_D11_F16_C1: Where can I learn more about these foundations?
S3.S3_D12_F17_C2: Ah, I know just the scroll we need.

help.heading: Understanding Euclid's Postulates:
help.body:
• Each postulate shows a basic geometric truth
  • We accept these without proof
  • These form the foundation of geometry
  • Note the simple diagrams illustrating each statement

about.heading: Observed Data
about.body:
Euclid's Five Postulates are the building blocks of geometry:
  1. Points can be connected by straight lines
  2. Lines can be extended indefinitely
  3. Circles can be drawn with any center and radius
  4. All right angles are equal
  5. Parallel line property (The parallel postulate) - If two lines are parallel, a line crossing them will make interior angles on each side that sum to 180°

postulate1.name: Postulate 1 - Line Segment Postulate
postulate1.title: A line can be drawn from any point to any point
postulate1.description: A straight line segment connects two distinct points, represented as dots, with a continuous line stretching between them.

postulate2.name: Postulate 2 - Extension Postulate
postulate2.title: A finite straight line can be continuously extended
postulate2.description: A straight line segment is shown extending infinitely in both directions, with dashed lines indicating the extension beyond the original endpoints.

postulate3.name: Postulate 3 - Circle Postulate
postulate3.title: A circle can be drawn with any center and any radius
postulate3.description: A circle is depicted with a central point and a radius extending outward, forming a perfect round shape.

postulate4.name: Postulate 4 - Right Angle Postulate
postulate4.title: All right angles are equal to one another
postulate4.description: Two right angles are shown, each formed by perpendicular lines intersecting at 90 degrees, demonstrating their equality.

postulate5.name: Postulate 5 - Parallel Lines Postulate
postulate5.title: If two lines are parallel, a line crossing them will make interior angles on each side that sum to 180°
postulate5.description: Two parallel lines are crossed by a transversal, with the interior angles on the same side summing to 180 degrees, illustrating the parallel postulate.

S4.S4_D1_F19_C1: These diagrams are beautiful!
S4.S4_D2_F20_C3: These are what we call Euclid's postulates. See how clearly they're written?
S4.S4_D3_F21_C2: Here's the first postulate: a straight line can be drawn from any point to any point.
S4.S4_D4_F22_C2: Remember, like all postulates, we simply accept this as true! Just as a chain begins with its strongest link, our geometric proofs begin with these fundamental truths.
S4.S4_D5_F23_C3: Or that all right angles are equal to one another. These are our unbreakable first links.
S4.S4_D6_F24_C1: So using these basic truths, we can build new ideas step by step?
S4.S4_D7_F25_C2: Exactly! Each proof must connect perfectly to the ones before it. If I prove something about intersecting lines, I can use that truth to understand their angles—and build further proofs from there.
S4.S4_D8_F26_C3: And that exactly is our task, to understand the set of proofs and connect them with each other.
S4.S4_D9_F27_C1: So what is the first link in the chain?
S4.S4_D10_F28_C2: The simplest case: what happens when two lines cross. Let's go to the oldest part of the library where ancient mathematicians first discovered these truths.

S5_D0_F31_C9.title: Vertical Angles Theorem

help.heading: Understanding Euclid's Postulates:
help.body:
Draw geometric figures and discover key relationships between angles:

  • Draw two intersecting lines
  • Drag and drop angles to explore relationships
  • Fill in equations to build proofs
  • Follow Hypatia's guidance to understand each step

about.heading: Observed Data
about.body:
Journey through fundamental theorems of geometry:

Vertical Angles: When two lines intersect, opposite angles are equal.

step1.title: Step 1: Draw 2 Intersecting Lines
step1.instruction: Draw your magical lines by clicking and dragging

step2.title: Step 2: Discover The Angles
step2.instruction: Observe the four mystical angles formed

step3.title: Step 3: Prove The Theory
step3.instruction: Use Euclid's ancient tools to complete the proof

definition1.label: Definition
definition1.description: The angles on a straight line sum to 180°

notion1.label: Common Notion 1
notion1.description: Things equal to the same thing are equal to each other

notion3.label: Common Notion 3
notion3.description: If equals are subtracted from equals, the remainders are equal

postulate2.label: Postulate 2
postulate2.description: To produce a finite straight line continuously
postulate2.popoverDescription: A straight line segment is shown extending infinitely in both directions, with dashed lines indicating the extension beyond the original endpoints

summary.title: Vertical Angles Theorem
summary.description: When two lines intersect, the angles opposite to each other are equal:

errors.sameAngles: You've used the same angles as before. Choose different angles to proceed.
errors.noCommonAngle: You must use at least one angle from the first equation in your second equation.
errors.notAdjacent: These angles are not supplementary. Try a pair of adjacent angles.
errors.positionOccupied: This position is already occupied. Please choose another position.
errors.linesMustIntersect: Lines must intersect! Try drawing them again.

steps.adjacentAngles: Adjacent angles on a straight line sum to 180°
steps.commonNotion3: By Common Notion 3: If equals are subtracted from equals, the remainders are equal
steps.commonNotion1: By Common Notion 1 (things equal to the same thing are equal)
steps.verticalAnglesEqual: Therefore, these angles are vertical and equal
steps.verticalAnglesProof: We have proved that when two lines intersect, the angles opposite to each other are equal

step1.title: Step 1: Draw 2 intersecting Lines
step1.instruction: Draw your magical lines by clicking and dragging

step2.title: Step 2: Discover The Angles
step2.instruction: Observe the angles formed by the intersection
step2.equationTitle: Step 2: Adjacent Angles at First Intersection

step3.title: Step 2: Match the First Set of Angles
step3.instruction: Drag and drop angles to complete the first equation
step3.equationTitle: Step 3: Adjacent Angles at Second Intersection

step4.title: Step 3: Match the Second Set of Angles
step4.instruction: Drag and drop angles to complete the second equation

S5_D0_F31_C9.drawDefaultLinesAriaLabel: Two intersecting lines formed on the canvas

S5.S5_D1_F31_C3: Shall we examine this first proof together?
S5.S5_D2_F32_C2: Yes, this scroll contains one of our oldest proofs. Akila, can you draw two intersecting lines and tell what you notice?
S5.S5_D3_F33_C1: Two lines intersect… and they create four angles.
S5.S5_D4_F34_C3: Exactly, Akila. And here is a question for you: do you notice pairs of angles that seem to stand opposite each other?
S5.S5_D5_F35_C1: Yes! ∠a and ∠c are opposite, and so are ∠b and ∠d. They're like mirror images across the intersection!
S5.S5_D6_F36_C2: Well observed. These are called vertical angles. Now here's the remarkable property we're going to prove: vertical angles are always equal. Once we prove this, we can use it anytime without having to prove it again.
S5.S5_D7_F37_C1: Are they always equal? How do we know for sure?
S5.S5_D8_F38_C2: Answering your first question, yes they are always equal! Take a moment to observe them closely. Can you fill in the pairs of angles that seem related? Drag and drop the values into the boxes with what you notice.
S5.S5_D9_F39_C2: Well done! You've identified an important relationship.
S5.S5_DX_FX_C1: Because they're on a straight line... and there are two angles on the straight line!
S5.S5_D10_F42_C2: Exactly! And remember what we know about angles on a straight line?
S5.S5_D11_F43_C1: They always add up to 180°!
S5.S5_D12_F44_C2: Great! Now, can you find another pair of angles that also add up to 180° and share one of these angles?
S5.S5_D13_F45_C2: Excellent! Let's reason this through. Both pairs make 180° because they lie on straight lines. They also share a common angle.
S5.S5_D14_F46_C1: Ah! So if we take away the same angle or subtract it from 180° in both cases, what remains must be equal!
S5.S5_D15_F47_C3: Beautiful reasoning! You've discovered one of geometry's fundamental truths - vertical angles are always equal. Here, ∠a = ∠c and ∠b = ∠d. And you didn't just learn it - you proved it!

S6.S6_D1_F49_C1: Looking at all these ancient scrolls around us... each one must contain a different proof. So now that we've proven vertical angles are always equal, how does this help us with proving a triangle to have 180°?
S6.S6_D2_F50_C2: Among these shelves lies every theorem we'll need. Here...This one contains our next proof.

S7_D0_F53_C9.title: Corresponding Angles Theorem

help.heading: Understanding Euclid's Postulates:
help.body:
The interior region refers to the space between two parallel lines when they are intersected by a transversal.


Draw geometric figures and discover key relationships between angles:

  • Draw a line and the parallel line appears
  • Draw the transversal
  • Drag and drop angles to explore relationships
  • Fill in equations to build proofs
  • Follow Hypatia's guidance to understand each step

about.heading: Observed Data
about.body:
Journey through fundamental theorems of geometry:

Corresponding Angles: When parallel lines are cut by a transversal, angles in matching positions are equal.

step0.title: Step 1: Draw the First Line
step0.instruction: Click and drag to draw the first line

step1.title: Step 2: Draw the Transversal
step1.instruction: Click and drag to draw a line that intersects both parallel lines

step3.title: Step 4: Prove First Corresponding Angle
step3.instruction: Use the given tools to prove that the first corresponding angles are equal

step4.title: Step 5: Prove Second Corresponding Angle
step4.instruction: Use the given tools to prove that the second corresponding angles are equal

commonNotion3.label: Common Notion 3
commonNotion3.description: If equals are subtracted from equals, the remainders are equal.

parallelPostulate.label: Parallel Postulate
parallelPostulate.description: If two lines are parallel, a line crossing them will make interior angles on each side that sum to 180°.
parallelPostulate.postulateDescription: Two parallel lines are crossed by a transversal, with the interior angles on the same side summing to 180 degrees, illustrating the parallel postulate.

supplementaryAngles.label: Supplementary Angles
supplementaryAngles.description: When two angles form a straight line, they sum to 180°.

proof.firstEquation: Step 1: Supplementary Angles at First Intersection
proof.firstEquationExplanation: (Angles on a straight line are supplementary)
proof.secondEquation: Step 2: Same-side Interior Angles at Second Intersection
proof.secondEquationExplanation: (Parallel Postulate: If two lines are parallel, a line crossing them will make interior angles on each side that sum to 180°.)

summary.title: Summary
summary.description: Therefore, corresponding angles ∠a and ∠b are equal. By Common Notion 3: If equals are subtracted from equals, the remainders are equal. Since ∠a + ∠c = 180° and ∠b + ∠c = 180°, therefore ∠a = ∠b.

errors.linesMustIntersect: Transversal must intersect both the lines! Try drawing them again.
errors.notSupplementary: These angles are not supplementary angles at the first intersection.
errors.notSameSideInterior: These are not same-side interior angles at the second intersection.

S7_D0_F53_C9.thereforeText: Therefore, corresponding angles ∠a and ∠b are equal.
S7_D0_F53_C9.commonNotion3: By Common Notion 3: If equals are subtracted from equals, the remainders are equal. Since ∠a + ∠c = 180° and ∠b + ∠c = 180°, therefore ∠a = ∠b.
S7_D0_F53_C9.drawLinesAriaLabel: Two parallel lines formed on the canvas
S7_D0_F53_C9.drawTransversalAriaLabel: Transversal line formed on the canvas

S7.S7_D1_F53_C2: Now that we understand vertical angles, let's see what happens when we have parallel lines.
S7.S7_D2_F55_C3: First, let's draw one line, we will create another line parallel to it.
S7.S7_D3_FX_C1: Like two lines that never meet?
S7.S7_D4_F56_C2: Exactly! Now, see the parallel line - notice how it maintains the same distance throughout?
S7.S7_D5_F57_C3: Beautiful! But to study the angles between these parallel lines, we need something else, a transversal line...
S7.S7_D6_F59_C2: A line that crosses both parallel lines Try drawing one that intersects both lines.
S7.S7_D8_F61_C3: Indeed! When a transversal crosses parallel lines, it creates some fascinating angle relationships.
S7.S7_D9_F62_C2: Do you notice how some of them appear in matching positions at each intersection?
S7.S7_D10_F63_C1: Yes! Like this ∠a up here and ∠b down there - they're in the same position!
S7.S7_D11_F64_C2: Those are called corresponding angles. Now, let's prove they're equal using what we know about angles on a straight line.
S7.S7_D12_F65_C2: Let's look at these angles at the first intersection on l1. When two angles lie on a straight line like this...
S7.S7_D14_FX_C1: So ∠a plus ∠c equals 180°.
S7.S7_D15_F68_C2: Correct! Now look at the interior angles formed when the transversal crosses both parallel lines l1 and l2. What do you notice about these angles?
S7.S7_D16_F69_C1: Because lines l1 and l2 are parallel, that makes ∠b and ∠c interior angles, which means they must sum to 180°— that was one of our postulates!
S7.S7_D17_FX_C3: Can you tell which postulate it is?
S7.S7_D18_F70_C3: Now, think carefully - we have two equations now. What does this tell us about ∠a and ∠b?
S7.S7_D19_F71_C1: Well... if ∠a + ∠c = 180° and ∠b + ∠c = 180°... then say ∠a + ∠c must equal ∠b + ∠c, because things equal to the same thing are equal to each other.
S7.S7_D20_FX_C1: Therefore, we can then conclude that ∠a is equal to ∠b because if equals are subtracted from equals, the remainders are equal.
S7.S7_D21_F72_C2: You are starting to get the hang of it! We are going pretty fast now, we have already proved two theorems.

S8.S8_D1_F74_C1: So corresponding angles are always equal when lines are parallel… I still do not understand how this has anything to do with triangles.
S8.S8_D2_F75_C2: That is understandable, it is pretty complex. Remember how we're building our chain of understanding link by link?
S8.S8_D3_F76_C1: Yes - each proof builds on the ones before it.
S8.S8_D4_F77_C3: And these parallel lines have given us a powerful tool. Look at the angles we just proved are equal...
S8.S8_D6_F79_C2: Indeed. But there's another special set of angles created by our transversal. We can now use the theorem on corresponding angles, together with the one on vertical angles!

help.heading: Understanding Euclid's Postulates:
help.body:
The interior region refers to the space between two parallel lines when they are intersected by a transversal.


Draw geometric figures and discover key relationships between angles:

  • Draw a line and the parallel line appears
  • Draw the transversal
  • Drag and drop angles to explore relationships
  • Fill in equations to build proofs
  • Follow Hypatia's guidance to understand each step

info.heading: Observed Data
info.body:
Journey through fundamental theorems of geometry:

Alternate Interior Angles: When parallel lines are cut by a transversal, angles between the lines on opposite sides are equal.

step1.title: Step 1: Construct Parallel Lines
step1.instruction: First, draw a line. Then click a point to create its parallel line using Euclid's Fifth Postulate

step2.title: Step 2: Draw a Transversal
step2.instruction: Draw a line intersecting both parallel lines to create corresponding angles and alternate interior angles

step3.title: Step 3: Prove Alternate Interior Angles
step3.instruction: Use corresponding angles and vertical opposite angles to prove they are equal

corresponding.title: Step 1: Corresponding Angles
corresponding.statement: ∠d = ∠c

verticalOpposite.title: Step 2: Identify vertical opposite angles
verticalOpposite.statement: ∠x = ∠d
verticalOpposite.explanation: Vertically opposite angles on two intersecting lines

errors.intersection: The transversal must intersect both parallel lines! Try drawing it again.
errors.corresponding: These angles are not corresponding angles. Look for angles on the same side of the transversal.
errors.verticalOpposite: These angles are not vertically opposite angles. Look for opposite angles on the intersection of two lines.
errors.defaultMessage: Lines must intersect! Try drawing them again.

parallelSection.title: Understanding Parallel Lines and Transversal:
parallelSection.description: When a transversal intersects two parallel lines:

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.explanation: Alternate interior angles are equal when two parallel lines are cut by a transversal

generalVisualization.title: General Theorem Visualization
generalVisualization.description: When a transversal intersects two parallel lines, alternate interior angles ( b ) are equal.

principles.title: Corresponding Angles:
principles.description: When two lines are cut by a transversal, corresponding angles are equal

principles.title: Vertical Angles:
principles.description: Angles opposite each other when two lines intersect are equal

proofConclusion.title: Therefore, by corresponding angles and vertically opposite angles,

S9.S9_D1_F82_C3: Let's draw the parallel lines again, but this time, we'll look at different pairs of angles.
S9.S9_D2_F83_C1: It's keeping the same distance throughout, just like before!
S9.S9_D3_F84_C3: Now, let’s draw the transversal line.
S9.S9_D4_F85_C1: I see many angles again... but which ones are we looking at this time?
S9.S9_D5_F86_C2: Look at the angles between our parallel lines - we call this the interior region. Do you see any angles that seem to mirror each other?
S9.S9_D6_F87_C1: Oh! The ∠x on the left of the transversal, and the ∠c on the right... they're like reflected versions of each other!
S9.S9_D7_F88_C3: Those are our alternate interior angles. But how can we prove they're equal?
S9.S9_D8_F89_C2: Think about what we just learned about corresponding angles. Could that help us?
S9.S9_D9_F90_C1: Well... we just proved that corresponding angles are equal, right?
S9.S9_D10_F91_C2: Yes, that's our first strong link in this proof. Can you spot a corresponding angle pair?
S9.S9_D11_F92_C3: Excellent Akila! So we know these angles are equal. What else do you notice at this intersection?
S9.S9_D12_F93_C1: Wait... I see something familiar from our first chain! These two angles at the crossing point...
S9.S9_D13_F94_C2: They form what kind of angles?
S9.S9_D14_F95_C1: Vertical angles! Like we proved before - they must be equal!
S9.S9_D15_F96_C2: Perfect! Consider this - ∠c is equal to ∠d because they are corresponding angles. ∠x is equal to ∠d because they are vertical angles.
S9.S9_D16_F97_C1: Ah! So ∠c must equal ∠x - because things equal to the same thing are equal to each other! They're alternate interior angles!
S9.S9_D17_F98_C2: By connecting what we learned about vertical angles with corresponding angles, we've proven something completely new - alternate interior angles are always equal. Another strong link in our chain!
S9.S9_D18_F99_C1: So when lines are parallel, these alternate interior angles are always equal... but I still can't see how this helps us prove that triangles have 180°.
S9.S9_D19_F100_C2: We're closer than you think! Now that we understand alternate interior angles, we have everything we need for the final proof!

S10.S10_D1_F104_C2: Look around you, Akila. Every scroll has given us a tool we needed - vertical angles, corresponding angles, alternate interior angles. Like pieces of a puzzle waiting to be connected.
S10.S10_D2_F105_C1: Now that we have all our tools, shall we put them to use? Let's start with a triangle...

S11_D0_F108_C9.title: Triangle Angle Sum Theorem

help.heading: Understanding Euclid's Postulates:
help.body:
Draw geometric figures and discover key relationships between angles:

  • Click points to create triangle
  • Drag and drop angles to explore relationships
  • Fill in equations to build proofs
  • Follow Hypatia's guidance to understand each step

about.heading: Observed Data
about.body:
Journey through fundamental theorems of geometry:

Triangle Angle Sum: The three angles in any triangle add up to 180 degrees.

step1.title: Step 1: Draw a Triangle
step1.instruction: Click three points to create triangle ABC.

step2.title: Step 2: Draw Parallel Line
step2.instruction: Through point A, draw a line parallel to BC.

step3.title: Step 3: Identify Angle Relationships
step3.instruction: Use angle relationships to prove the sum is 180°.

keyPrinciples.parallelLinesDesc: When two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, alternate interior angles are equal.
keyPrinciples.straightAnglesDesc: Angles that form a straight line sum to 180°.

altInterior1.title: Step 1: First Alternate Interior Angles
altInterior1.explanation: Alternate interior angles formed by the transversal intersecting the parallel lines.

altInterior2.title: Step 2: Second Alternate Interior Angles
altInterior2.explanation: Alternate interior angles formed by the transversal intersecting the parallel lines.

straightLine.title: Step 3: Angles on a Straight Line
straightLine.explanation: Angles forming a straight line sum to 180°.

proof.finalStatement: Therefore, the sum of the interior angles is 180°.
proof.errorStatement: Invalid angle triplet! Try a different combination of angles.
proof.summaryText: The sum of interior angles in any triangle is always 180°.
proof.invalidPair: Select a valid pair of alternate interior angles

errorMessages.invalidTriangle: Please ensure your triangle points are properly placed and form a valid triangle.

summary.description: The sum of interior angles in any triangle equals 180°:

S11_D0_F108_C9.trianglePlaced: Triangle ABC placed on the canvas

S11.S11_D1_F108_C3: Let's prove triangles to always be 180°! Let's draw one!
S11.S11_D2_F109_C2: Yes - we'll create our triangle point by point. Start by choosing where you want point A to be.
S11.S11_D3_F110_C3: Good. Now for point B - make it a large triangle, so it is easier to see
S11.S11_DX1_FX_C3: And finally, choose the point C.
S11.S11_D4_F111_C2: Perfect! Now that we have our triangle, let's use Euclid's parallel postulate. Through point A, we can draw a line parallel to BC.
S11.S11_D5_F112_C1: Oh! I see what you're doing - just like in the earlier proofs The parallel line created new angles with our triangle sides.
S11.S11_D6_F113_C2: Let's identify these angles carefully. First, find a pair of alternate interior angles.
S11.S11_D7_F114_C1: Since we have parallel lines l1 and l2 cut by a transversal, these angles must be equal!
S11.S11_D8_F115_C3: Excellent! Can you find another pair of such angles, with a different transversal line?
S11.S11_D9_F116_C2: Exactly! We have in total two pairs of alternate interior angles.
S11.S11_D10_FX_C3: Now for the final piece - look at point A. What do you notice about ∠x, ∠a, and ∠y?
S11.S11_D11_FX_C1: These three angles at A... they make a straight line, so they sum to 180°!
S11.S11_D12_FX_C2: Now put all these pieces together. What have we discovered about the angles in our triangle?
S11.S11_D13_FX_C1: Well... ∠x = ∠b, and ∠y = ∠c... so if ∠x + ∠a + ∠y = 180°, then we can substitute in ∠b and ∠c to say that ∠b + ∠a + ∠c must also equal 180°! The angles in our triangle sum to 180°!
S11.S11_D15_FX_C1: Every triangle! We've finally proved it!

S12.S12_D1_F123_C3: And you discovered this not by taking someone's word for it, but by building your own chain of reasoning.
S12.S12_D2_F124_C1: Each scroll gave us something we needed - vertical angles, corresponding angles, alternate interior angles... It's like each step was leading us here all along!
S12.S12_D3_F125_C2: That's the true power of geometry, Akila. Starting with just those basic postulates we accepted as true, we carefully connected, and can unlock the mysteries that surround us.
S12.S12_D4_F126_C1: To think this is true for every triangle that ever was or will be drawn...
S12.S12_D5_F127_C3: And now you don't just know it's true...
S12.S12_D6_F128_C1: I understand why it must be true! Like seeing the inner workings of the universe itself!
S12.S12_D7_F129_C2: You wanted to understand why triangles have 180°, and now you've proven it yourself, step by step. This is how we build geometric knowledge - one proof at a time.
S12.S12_D8_F130_C1: Thank you, Hypatia. I am excited to prove even more new theorems, that would be very cool!

quest_completion.subheading: Euclid's Path: A Journey Through Geometry
quest_completion.content:
You completed Euclid's Path: A Journey Through Geometry.
  • You helped Hypatia and Akila explore the foundational theorems of parallel lines and angles
  • You explored proofs using Euclid's postulates and common notions
  • You discovered how theorems build upon each other from vertical angles to corresponding angles to alternate interior angles
  • You proved the Triangle-Angle Sum theorem using knowledge gained through those three proof angles

Just as Euclid's Elements has inspired mathematicians for over two millennia, may your journey through geometry continue to spark curiosity and logical thinking in all your future explorations!

proof.definition: Proof is a logical argument that uses definitions, axioms, postulates, and theorems to demonstrate why a statement is true, building a chain of deductions to reach a valid conclusion.

proofs.definition: Proofs are logical arguments that use definitions, axioms, postulates, and theorems to demonstrate why a statement is true, building a chain of deductions to reach a valid conclusion.

postulate.definition: Postulate is a statement that is accepted without proof as a basis for further reasoning. Euclid's postulates form the foundation of geometric proofs.

postulates.definition: Postulates are statements that is accepted without proof as a basis for further reasoning. Euclid's postulates form the foundation of geometric proofs.

common_notion.definition: Common Notion refers to basic logical principles that are self-evident truths, such as 'things equal to the same thing are equal to each other.'

corresponding_angles.definition: Corresponding Angles are angles in matching corners when a line (transversal) intersects two other lines. They occupy the same relative position at each intersection.

alternate_interior_angles.definition: Alternate Interior Angles are angles that lie on opposite sides of a transversal and between two lines. When the lines are parallel, these angles are equal.

vertical_angles.definition: Vertical Angles are angles that are opposite each other when two lines intersect. They are formed by two intersecting lines and are always equal in measure.

transversal.definition: Transversal is a line that intersects two or more other lines. It creates various angle relationships that are crucial in geometric proofs.

linear_pair.definition: Linear Pair refers to two adjacent angles that form a straight line, always summing to 180°.

intersection.definition: Intersection is the point where two or more lines, curves, or surfaces meet and cross each other.

triangle.definition: Triangle is a polygon with exactly 3 sides.

triangles.definition: Triangles are a polygon with exactly 3 sides.

interior_region.definition: Interior region refers to the space between two parallel lines when they are intersected by a transversal.

common.akila_description: An Egyptian architecture student with wavy dark hair wearing a white draped tunic, holding scrolls.
common.hypatia_description: A mathematician from Alexandria in blue and white robes with gold accents.
common.theon_description: A senior mathematician, elderly bearded man in classical robes holding a scroll.
common.bg1_description: Egyptian temple with obelisk, palm trees, people, and outdoor café in warm light.
common.bg2_description: Ancient library with towering bookshelves, people exploring, and a central obelisk.
common.bg3_description: Interior of a library filled with books and scrolls, where people are reading.
common.bg4_description: A grand hall filled with books, where a person is reading by sunlight.
common.bg5_description: A library bustling with people, featuring books, murals, and sunlight casting shadows.
common.bg6_description: A library scene where people are engaged with scrolls, surrounded by murals and columns.
common.invalid_pair: Invalid Pair! Try a different combination of angles
common.focusModeAnnouncement: Please toggle to focus mode to select angles and drop them in the correct locations.
